Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Act provides an alternative administrative procedure for redress, thereby excluding jurisdiction from the grievance process under s. 91(1) of the Public Service Staff Relations Act
Governing_Law: Public Service Staff Relations Act, s. 91(1)
Evidence_Assessment: Timing differences between CHRA and grievance procedures were not proven significant
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show no alternative redress mechanism exists
Legal_Rule: Under s. 91(1) of the Public Service Staff Relations Act, grievances are excluded if another administrative procedure for redress exists under an Act of Parliament
Procedural_Issue: Jurisdictional exclusion due to existence of alternative remedy
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged discrimination under Article 44 of the collective agreement
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached – dismissed on jurisdictional grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence and scope of remedies under CHRA
Legal_Framework: Interaction between collective agreement and federal human rights regime
Applicant_Challenge: Challenge to adjudicator's lack of jurisdiction
Legal_Rule_Source: Public Service Staff Relations Act, s. 91(1)
Outcome: Grievance excluded from process due to CHRA availability
Resolution_Mechanism: Human rights complaint process under CHRA
Legal_Provision: s. 91(1), Public Service Staff Relations Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 91(1), Public Service Staff Relations Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Jurisdictional bar under s. 91(1) due to alternative remedy
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Judicial review of adjudicator's jurisdictional ruling
Jurisdiction: Excluded – alternative statutory remedy under CHRA
Governing_Rule: s. 91(1), Public Service Staff Relations Act
